description: The adjective is derived from Late Middle English habitual (“of one's inherent disposition”), from Medieval Latin habituālis (“customary; habitual”), from Latin habitus (“character; disposition; habit; physical or emotional condition; attire, dress”) + -ālis (suffix forming adjectives of relationship); analysable as habit +‎ -ual. Habitus is derived from habeō (“to have; to hold; to own; to possess”) (possibly ultimately from Proto-Indo-European *gʰeh₁bʰ- (“to grab, take”)) + -tus (suffix forming action nouns from verbs).
The noun is derived from the adjective.

adjectives.description: habitual (comparative more habitual, superlative most habitual)

entries.meaning: Of or relating to a habit; established as a habit; performed over and over again; recurrent, recurring.
examples: Her habitual lying was the reason for my mistrust.
Professor Franklein took his habitual seat at the conference table.

entries.meaning: Of a person or thing: engaging in some behaviour as a habit or regularly.
(grammar) Pertaining to an action performed customarily, ordinarily, or usually.
(colloquial) One who does something habitually, such as a serial criminal offender.
(grammar) A construction representing something done habitually.
